title: 105_s1907
content: REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR WETLAND RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EXPENSES: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on wetland restoration and conservation expenses. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration, conservation, and easement expenses incurred during the taxable year. The wetland restoration credit is based on the expenditures made by the taxpayer for restoring wetlands. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures incurred during the taxable year. Wetland restoration expenditure refers to the restoration of farmed or converted wetlands to fully functioning wetland condition, following an approved restoration plan within the first 5 years of a conservation agreement or easement. The wetland conservation credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures incurred during the taxable year. This credit is based on the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate for the taxpayer's qualified wetland under the Food Security Act of 1985. The wetland conservation credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures incurred during the taxable year. The credit is based on the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate for the taxpayer's qualified wetland under the Food Security Act of 1985. The applicable percentage varies based on the term of the qualified conservation agreement. The wetland conservation credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures based on the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate. The credit percentage varies depending on the term of the conservation agreement. If a taxpayer elects the wetland easement credit, the conservation credit for that wetland is zero. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit equal to the fair market value of qualified wetlands subject to a conservation easement. The value is determined by a certified appraisal during the taxable year. An election under this subsection applies to the year it is made. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to a taxpayer who owns wetlands, farmed wetlands, or prior converted wetlands along with actively farmed cropland, and has entered into a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a qualified wetland, which includes wetlands being converted to fully functioning wetland condition through restoration expenditures and surrounded by a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The curr_chunk defines a conservation easement for wetlands, specifying that surrounding nonwetland acreage must not exceed 3 times the wetland acreage. It excludes land receiving payments from the Conservation Reserve Program. The curr_chunk defines wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland according to the Food Security Act of 1985. It also explains the term qualified conservation agreement as an agreement with a governmental unit by the eligible taxpayer. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for a taxpayer to enter into a conservation agreement with a governmental unit for a qualified wetland, lasting between 10 to 30 years. Compliance with conservation requirements and obtaining certification every 5 years is mandatory. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland, including not using it for agricultural production and refraining from any activities that alter the wetland. Certification every 5 years is mandatory. The term 'qualified conservation easement' refers to an easement granted in perpetuity by the taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for agricultural production or development, ensuring conservation of the wetland. The tax code prohibits claiming a credit for expenses already deducted elsewhere or funded by government programs when donating a qualified wetland for conservation purposes. The tax code requires married couples to file joint returns for this section to apply. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax code requires married couples to file joint returns for this section to apply. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The last item is amended by inserting the following. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1998.
